S3.T1.caption: Table 1: Coefficients ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡j(τ)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝜏\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(\tau)} for different FL schemes including FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), Scaffold (Karimireddy et al., 2020), FedProx (Li et al., 2020), FedDyn (Acar et al., 2021) and FedDC (Gao et al., 2022). Here m𝑚m denotes the number of local epochs, τ𝜏\tau is the index of a local epoch, η𝜂\eta is the learning rate, and Δ​𝐛j(r)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐛𝑗𝑟\Delta\mathbf{b}_{j}^{(r)} denotes the j𝑗j-th component of the local update of bias 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} in global round r𝑟r. For FedDC, Δ​𝐁j(r)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝐁𝑗𝑟\Delta\mathbf{B}_{j}^{(r)} denotes the j𝑗j-th component of the global update of bias 𝐛𝐛\mathbf{b} while 𝐝k(t)superscriptsubscript𝐝𝑘𝑡\mathbf{d}_{k}^{(t)} is the local drift in global round t𝑡t. The server in each of the schemes can collect the corresponding variables and potentially use them in a label recovery attack.

references:
where ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} is a constant that depends on hyper-parameters used by different methods and remains constant across global rounds, and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} is a term capturing historical training information (past local updates). We summarize the values of ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} for different FL schemes in Table 1 (derivations provided in Appendix A.4-A.9). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that studies label recovery attacks in FL schemes beyond FedAvg.
In FL schemes that utilize only the gradient information computed in the current global round (e.g., FedAvg and FedProx)
𝐡jt=𝟎superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}=\mathbf{0}, while for the schemes that also
rely on the past gradient information (Scaffold, FedDyn and FedDC)
𝐡jt≠𝟎superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡0\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t}\not=\mathbf{0}. In any case, ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡j(t)superscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{(t)} are known to the server and may potentially be used for label recovery attacks. In our work, we rely on the procedure for label recovery from local updates discussed in the previous section to run RLU attacks on different FL schemes where ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} and 𝐡jtsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝑗𝑡\mathbf{h}_{j}^{t} vary from one scheme to another according to Table 1.

The concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha controlling data partitioning is set to 0.50.50.5 in experiments on SVHN and CIFAR10, and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet. The optimizer used in all experiments is SGD.

references: A randomly initialized untrained model may be extremely vulnerable to label recovery attacks; for instance, if the server knows how the training is initialized, it does not even need an auxiliary data set to infer the parameters (e.g., 𝝁nsubscript𝝁𝑛\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n}) used in the attack. To compare the performance of baseline methods with that of RLU, we conduct comprehensive experiments on untrained models across various architectures, datasets, batch-sizes and activation functions. The results, reported in Table 2, demonstrate that RLU outperforms the baselines in all settings. When local training consists of a single epoch, RLU achieves near-perfect accuracy across the board in terms of both cAcc and iAcc; iRLG is a close second, outperforming other baselines. Since LLG+ assumes non-negative activation functions, its performance deteriorates significantly with Tanh and SELU. On Tiny-ImageNet, ZLG+ performs the worst among the four methods, achieving under 70%percent7070\% iAcc.

When the clients run m=10𝑚10m=10 local epochs, performance of all methods deteriorates (as expected based on the discussion in Section 3.2.2). Nevertheless, the results in Table 2 show that RLU still outperforms the baselines, maintaining at least 84%percent8484\% cACC and 90%percent9090\% iAcc on all datasets, architectures and activation functions. While iRLG maintains solid performance on SVHN and Tiny-ImageNet, it performs significantly worse on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 (iAcc falls below 70%percent7070\%, cAcc drops below 50%percent5050\%). The results of LLG+ follow the same pattern exhibited in single epoch settings, while ZLG+ experiences significant performance deterioration on SVHN. For consistency and a comparison with the results in Table 2, unless stated otherwise, in the remainder of this section the number of local epochs m𝑚m is set to 101010.

Since the accuracy of the global model improves as the training proceeds, comparing methods in terms of attacks on untrained model becomes no longer meaningful. As discussed in Section 3.2, distribution of output logits depends on the accuracy of the model which is parameterized by mean 𝝁nsubscript𝝁𝑛\boldsymbol{\mu}_{n} and covariance 𝚺nsubscript𝚺𝑛\boldsymbol{\Sigma}_{n}. When the model becomes highly accurate, magnitudes of local gradients (updates) start vanishing; this, in turn, causes high sensitivity to noise and a large error in estimating the labels. All of the methods in Table 2 experience performance deterioration as the model accuracy increases. To compare their robustness, we conduct extensive experiments and evaluate performance of different attack methods at different stages of training. As shown in Fig. 1, RLU outperforms the baselines at all training stages, achieving 80%percent8080\% iAcc when the model accuracy reaches 80%percent8080\%. For the global model achieving 90%percent9090\% training accuracy, iAcc of iRLG reaches 75.6%percent75.675.6\%, 83.3%percent83.383.3\% and 72.6%percent72.672.6\% on SVHN, CIFAR10 and CIFAR100, respectively. The iAcc of ZLG+ is 33.3%percent33.333.3\%, 21.1%percent21.121.1\% and 30.1%percent30.130.1\% lower than RLU’s, while iRLG’s trails RLU by 16.3%percent16.316.3\%, 17.3%percent17.317.3\% and 23.9%percent23.923.9\% on these three datasets, respectively. The iAcc performance of LLG+ is better than that of other prior methods but still falls significantly behind RLU’s.

The learning rate η𝜂\eta for the SGD optimizer was set to 0.010.010.01 in all experiments reported in Table 2. In order to obtain high level of data heterogeneity, we set the concentration parameters α𝛼\alpha to 0.50.50.5 in the experiments on SVHN and CIFAR10; in the experiments on CIFAR100 and Tiny-ImageNet, this parameter was set to 0.10.10.1. There are two groups of experiments in Table 2; in one the number of local epochs m𝑚m was set to 111, while in the other it was set to 101010. For the experiments involving multiple local epochs, the number of iterations T𝑇T in Alg. 2 was set to 101010.

Here we explored the effect of data heterogeneity controlled by varying the concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha from 0.050.050.05 to 555. For a fair comparison, we set the number of local epochs to m=10𝑚10m=10; other settings were identical to the settings in Table 2.

Similar to Table 2 and Table LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs m𝑚m to 101010 in all experiments reported in Table 4, Figure 1 and Figure 2. The concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate η𝜂\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

references: Data heterogeneity is one the main challenges in real-world applications of federated learning. Prior works on label reconstruction evaluated their proposed methods on i.i.d. data, but the evaluation on non-i.i.d. data has remained largely unexplored. To this end, we benchmark the methods considered in this paper on CIFAR10 data partitions generated for varied values of

references: To the best of our knowledge, prior works evaluate their methods only on FedAvg. While FedAvg is indeed the oldest and perhaps the most widely used FL scheme, a number of other FL schemes has grown to prominence yet remains largely unexplored in the context of label recovery. As discussed in Section 3.3, we provide a framework to conduct label recovery attacks on several regularization-based FL schemes that may be using various optimizers. Table 4 shows the superior performance of RLU in the experiments on FedProx and SGDm. As can be seen from the table, in the experiments where λ=0.5𝜆0.5\lambda=0.5 and γ=0.1𝛾0.1\gamma=0.1 (which leads to ρ(τ)≈1superscript𝜌𝜏1\rho^{(\tau)}\approx 1), the three baselines achieve performance similar to that in their attacks on FedAvg. However, as ρ(τ)superscript𝜌𝜏\rho^{(\tau)} deviates from 111 when λ=5𝜆5\lambda=5 and γ=0.9𝛾0.9\gamma=0.9, performance of the baselines severely deteriorates while RLU maintain its iAcc of at least 88%percent8888\%.

Similar to Table 2 and Table LABEL:table3, we set the number of local epochs m𝑚m to 101010 in all experiments reported in Table 4, Figure 1 and Figure 2. The concentration parameter α𝛼\alpha was set to 0.50.50.5 on SVHN/CIFAR10 and to 0.10.10.1 on CIFAR100. The learning rate η𝜂\eta was set to 0.010.010.01 in experiments on SVHN and to 0.050.050.05 in experiments on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100.

A2.T5.caption: Table 5: Comparison of RLU and state-of-the-art label recovery methods in FL. The “Batch” column indicates whether the method can recover labels in a batch or not; “Repeating Labels” column indicates if the method assumes no repeating labels in the batch; “Activation-agnostic” column indicates if the method can work beyond non-negative activation functions; “Multiple Epochs” column indicates if the method can recover labels from updates computed in multiple local epochs; “Trained Model” column indicates if the method preserve performance on well-trained models.

A check mark (✔) indicates that a method is suitable for a given setting while the cross mark (✗) indicates that it is not. As the table indicates, RLU is capable of operating in a variety of scenarios.
